conclusion: The device consists of a U-shaped tube with a bulb (B) and a container (C) connected by a tube.
The U-shaped tube has two arms, A and D, which are connected by a horizontal section.
Close the valve K and record the initial positions of the menisci in the U-shaped tube, called m and n.
The difference in height between the menisci gives the initial volume of gas in the system.
Open the valve K and allow the gas to expand as the solid is added to the container C.
The gas will expand and push the menisci in the U-shaped tube.
Record the new positions of the menisci, called m' and n'.
The volume of gas expelled is the difference in the volumes of the gas before and after the solid is added.
The volume of gas is given by the product of the pressure and the volume.
Since the pressure is constant (assuming the atmospheric pressure is constant), the volume change is directly proportional to the change in height of the menisci.
The volume of gas expelled is V_gas = (m' - m) × cross-sectional area of the U-tube.
The volume of the solid is equal to the volume of gas that was expelled from the system.
Therefore, the volume of the solid is V_solid = V_gas = (m' - m) × cross-sectional area of the U-tube.
The volume of the measured solid is V_solid = (m' - m) × cross-sectional area of the U-tube.
